page.title: 02 HISTORIC LEWES
page.content: {"Fine old buildings".}This is many people's first impression of Lewes. Careful conservation has preserved a rich variety of styles to the present day. The 11th century{castle}keep, built by a grateful follower of William 1, dominates the town from the top of its chalk block mound. A huge Cluniac{Priory}was ravaged by stone- stealers,Victorian railway builders and the weather,and largely neglected until recently. Its fine Caen lime- stone now adorns many buildings in Southover,notably{Anne of Cleves House and{Southover Grange,}an Elizabethan manor house,now marriage registry, public rooms and a pottery,with beautifully-kept public gardens. Queen Anne and Georgian houses form many High Street frontages,with frequent use of{knapped flint}or{math- {ematical tiles.Narrow twittens abound.
